questions.text: An investigator studying epigenetic mechanisms isolates histone proteins, the structural motifs involved in DNA binding and regulation of transcription. The peptide bonds of histone proteins are hydrolyzed and one type of amino acid is isolated. At normal body pH, this amino acid has a net charge of +1 . The investigator performs titration of this amino acid and obtains the graph shown. The isolated amino acid is most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serine is an amino acid whose side chain contains a hydroxyl group. This group is polar, but not charged, meaning that serine is neutral at body pH. Furthermore, since the side chain does not contain an ionizable group, the titration curve would only show two plateaus, not three.

B) CORRECT:

Lysine and arginine are strong basic amino acids with three ionizable groups: an α-amino group, an α-carboxyl group, and an ε-amino group. At body pH (7.35–7.45), the amino groups are protonated (NH3+) and the carboxyl group is deprotonated (COO‑), giving lysine a net charge of +1. The titration curve showed above mirrors the ionization of the three groups with changing pH: at a very low pH (high concentration of H+ ions) all three groups are protonated. After adding more OH--equivalents, first the carboxyl group gets deprotonated (first plateau, pKa1), then the α-amino group (second plateau, pKa2) and finally the ε-amino group (third plateau, pKa3).

Histones contain around 25% basic amino acids like lysine and arginine, which gives them their overall positive charge, an important characteristic necessary for binding with negatively charged DNA (e.g., to form a nucleosome). Lysines and arginines can be methylated (histone methylation), which is a means of controlling gene transcription.
Image Description:

Titration curve of the amino acid lysine, with changes in pH levels following the addition of a base. Also depicted here is the corresponding protonation state (as a structural formula).

Lysine is a basic amino acid and has three pKs values.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspartate is an acidic amino acid, since it contains a carboxyl group in its side chain. It would therefore show a titration curve with three plateaus as seen above. However, the carboxyl group is deprotonated at body pH, which leads to a net charge of -1, not +1.

D) INCORRECT:

Histidine has an imidazole side chain, which is ionizable. It would therefore show a titration curve with three plateaus (three pKa values) as seen above. However, histidine is only weakly basic (low pKa of 6) and is neutral rather than positively charged at body pH.

E) INCORRECT:

Proline is a nonpolar hydrophobic amino acid, meaning that it has no charge at body pH. Furthermore, since the side chain does not contain an ionizable group, the titration curve would only show two plateaus, not three.
questions.hint: At titration, amino acids are examined under changing pH conditions. The number of plateaus seen in the titration curve thereby corresponds with the number of ionizable groups an amino acid contains. Most amino acids have only two ionizable groups: the α-amino group, which is protonated at body pH, and the α-carboxyl group, which is deprotonated at body pH. Only amino acids with an ionizable side chain have a positive or negative net charge. An amino acid that has a net positive charge at body pH must have a side chain with strong basic properties.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of difficulty walking for 6 months. His mother reports that over the past year, he has been clumsy and does not seem to be able to concentrate when encouraged to play with his toys. During infancy, he had an episode of tonic-clonic seizure after an upper respiratory infection that required intubation. He is at the 10th percentile for length and below the 5th percentile for weight. Examination shows muscles that resist passive stretch and spastic movements of the upper and lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 throughout. Serum studies show:


Glucose
90 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
2 mg/dL


Ammonia

80 μmol/L (N = 11–35)



Urine



Orotic acid
increased


The results of a liver biopsy show that the hepatocytes are deficient in a particular enzyme. The enzyme is normally located in the cytosol of hepatocytes and the substrate of this enzyme is a proteinogenic amino acid that has a positive charge at a pH of 7.4. The patient most likely has a deficiency in which of the following labeled enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1) catalyzes the formation of carbamoyl phosphate from bicarbonate and ammonia. CPS1 deficiency causes hyperammonemia but CPS I is located in hepatic mitochondria rather than in cytosol, and its deficiency does not cause orotic acid accumulation in the urine. Additionally, neither bicarbonate nor ammonia are amino acids.

B) INCORRECT:

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) catalyzes the formation of citrulline from carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine. Ornithine has a positive charge at a pH of 7.4 and OTC deficiency, which is the most common urea cycle disorder, causes hyperammonemia and increased urine orotic acid concentrations. However, OTC is located in hepatic mitochondria rather than cytosol and ornithine is not a proteinogenic amino acid.

C) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinate synthetase catalyzes the formation of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate. This enzyme is located in the cytosol of hepatocytes and a deficiency of this enzyme can result in hyperammonemia and increased urine concentrations of orotic acid. However, citrulline is a nonproteinogenic amino acid with no charge at normal body pH (7.4) and although aspartate is proteinogenic, aspartate has a negative charge at normal body pH. A different amino acid involved in the urea cycle is both proteinogenic and positively charged at normal body pH.

D) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinate lyase, which catalyzes the breakdown of argininosuccinate to arginine and fumarate, is located in the cytosol of hepatocytes and a deficiency of this enzyme can cause hyperammonemia and an increase in urine concentrations of orotic acid. However. fumarate is not an amino acid, and although argininosuccinate is a basic amino acid, argininosuccinate is not proteinogenic.

E) CORRECT:

A defect of any enzyme involved in the urea cycle will cause the accumulation of ammonia and a decrease in the concentration of blood urea nitrogen. The urea cycle, which occurs in hepatocytes, involves the mitochondrial enzymes carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I) and ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) and the cytosolic enzymes argininosuccinate synthetase, argininosuccinate lyase, and arginase. Arginase catalyzes the breakdown of arginine, a proteinogenic amino acid with a positive charge at normal body pH (7.4), into urea and ornithine. Carbamoyl phosphate also accumulates in all urea cycle enzyme defects except CPS I deficiency. Carbamoyl phosphate is diverted to the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, causing an increase in orotic acid in serum and its subsequent excretion in urine.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.
questions.hint: This patient's developmental delay, failure to thrive, seizures, and muscle spasticity and weakness are likely due to his hyperammonemia. These features in combination with decreased blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and increased urinary orotic acid suggest a urea cycle disorder. A proteinogenic amino acid is one that is encoded by a codon and can be a component of a protein's primary structure.

questions.text: A 2-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because he became somnolent and felt cold after breastfeeding. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3538 g (7 lb 13 oz); he currently weighs 3311 g (7 lb 5 oz). Examination shows generalized hypotonia. Serum studies show an ammonia concentration of 150 μmol/L (N < 50). Fasting serum glucose concentration is normal. Accumulation of which of the following substances is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's neurological symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Under physiological conditions, α-ketoglutarate and ammonia act in equilibrium with glutamate in the central nervous system. When there is excess ammonia, however, this equilibrium shifts toward glutamate, reducing levels of α-ketoglutarate. Thus, hyperammonemia causes depletion rather than accumulation of α-ketoglutarate. Because α-ketoglutarate is also an important substrate of the citric acid cycle, its depletion can cause impairment of cerebral energy metabolism and subsequent neurologic dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of succinyl-CoA, an intermediate of the citric acid cycle synthesized from α-ketoglutarate, is not associated with any disorder presenting with hyperammonemia. In rare cases, neonatal hyperammonemia is due to methylmalonic acidemia, which is caused by impaired metabolism of methylmalonic acid and characteristically leads to decreased rather than increased succinyl-CoA concentrations.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased urea concentration is seen in uremic encephalopathy, which can manifest with somnolence and muscle weakness (e.g., hypotonia). However, uremic encephalopathy is caused by advanced renal failure, which would not explain this patient's elevated blood ammonia level. This patient most likely has a urea cycle disorder, which would cause an impaired ability to convert amino acids to urea, not an elevation in urea levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Acylcarnitines accumulate in CPT II deficiency, a disorder caused by impaired long-chain fatty acid oxidation in the mitochondria. Possible manifestations include somnolence, hypotonia, and hyperammonemia, all of which are seen here. However, in CPT II deficiency, fatty acids are not able to be used as substrates for gluconeogenesis, leading to hypoketotic fasting hypoglycemia. Conversely, this patient's serum glucose concentration is normal.

E) CORRECT:

Hyperammonemia results in the accumulation of glutamine, which plays an important role in the development of hepatic encephalopathy. Upon activation, neurons in the brain release neurotransmitters (e.g., glutamate, GABA) that are normally taken up from the synaptic cleft and recycled by astrocytes. In states of hyperammonemia, excess ammonia crosses the blood-brain barrier and enters into astrocytes. The astrocytes detoxify excess ammonia through the actions of glutamate dehydrogenase and glutamine synthetase. The consequent production of excess glutamine creates an osmotic effect that draws water into astrocytes and causes cellular swelling and dysfunction, resulting in cerebral edema that manifests with neurological symptoms such as those seen here.

While the accumulation of glutamine is one component of the pathogenesis of hepatic encephalopathy, the process is multifactorial and remains an area of ongoing study. In addition to the osmotic damage to astrocytes induced by the accumulation of glutamine, the metabolism of other neurotransmitters, including glutamate and GABA, is also disturbed in states of hyperammonemia. It is thought that these changes in metabolism lead to inhibition of excitatory neurotransmission and activation of inhibitory neurotransmission.
questions.hint: This neonate's hyperammonemia after feeding is most likely due to a urea cycle disorder. Ammonia is metabolized through the actions of glutamate dehydrogenase and glutamine synthetase.

questions.text:
An investigator performs a twin study to evaluate the effects of a novel drug that inhibits a transporter on the apical membrane of proximal convoluted tubule cells. The results of the study are shown.



Test
Control



Serum glucose (mg/dL)
92.4
99


Dipstick urine glucose
negative
negative


Urine pH
4.9
6.2



The drug most likely inhibits transport of which of the following substrates?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Glutamine enters the cells of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) by apical amino acid transporters that are responsible for the resorption of amino acids in the ultrafiltrate, as well as by transporters on the basolateral membrane that extract serum glutamine from peritubular capillaries. In the PCT cells, glutamine is catabolized to α-ketoglutarate (through the action of glutaminase and glutamate dehydrogenase) and two ammonia ions (NH4+). Gluconeogenesis further metabolizes α-ketoglutarate to glucose, which is released into the bloodstream; NH4+, in turn, is used as the primary form of hydrogen ion excretion in renal cells during acidosis. Therefore, inhibition of glutamine uptake in the PCT cells decreases both renal glucose production and NH4+ excretion in the urine. This results in slightly decreased serum glucose concentration without affecting urine glucose excretion. Furthermore, without the buffer of ammonium, urine pH decreases to < 5.5. Renal ammoniagenesis through catabolism of glutamine is an important compensatory pathway during states of acidosis.

PCT cells can also use lactate, glycerol, and alanine as substrates for gluconeogenesis but use glutamine at a 3-fold higher rate.

B) INCORRECT:

SGLT inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin) lower blood glucose by facilitating glucosuria and polyuria via reversible inhibition of the sodium-dependent glucose cotransporter in the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs). In contrast to this study's results, the administration of an SGLT inhibitor would result in positive urine glucose. Moreover, a decrease in urine pH would not be expected if sodium transport was inhibited.
Image Description:

The pars recta of the proximal tubule is referred to as thick descending limb of the loop of Henle. It is particularly responsible for the mainly paracellular absorption via leaky tight junctions or solvent drag. Hereby, mainly Cl− is transported out of the lumen, resulting in positive potential in the tubular lumen. In addition, specific glucose transporters (SGLT-1) carry Na+ and glucose via symport from the tubular lumen to the cell interior.

C) INCORRECT:

Catabolism of alanine by alanine-glutamate transaminase in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) cells produces glutamate and pyruvate in order to synthesize glucose. While inhibiting alanine uptake would indeed decrease glucose production, resulting in decreased blood sugar as seen here, it would not affect excreted hydrogen ions; therefore, it would not cause a decrease in urine pH.

In the liver, alanine is the predominant precursor for gluconeogenesis. But renal gluconeogenesis preferably uses a different substrate.
Image Description:

Alanine aminotransferase transfers the amino group (red) from alanine to α-ketoglutarate to yield pyruvate and glutamate. This transamination reaction is reversible and requires the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate (PLP).

D) INCORRECT:

Leucine is a ketogenic amino acid, so it can be metabolized to acetyl-CoA or fatty acids but cannot be used to produce glucose. Therefore, inhibiting its uptake in the PCT would not affect serum glucose or urine glucose. Moreover, a decrease in urine pH would not be expected if leucine transport was inhibited.

E) INCORRECT:

GLUT5 facilitates resorption of fructose in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). GLUT5 inhibitors decrease serum glucose and increase urine fructose, which is not detected on a urine dipstick, which would match this patient's findings. However, a decrease in urine pH would not be expected if fructose transport was inhibited.

GLUT-2 channels facilitate the reabsorption of glucose and fructose on the basolateral surface of PCT cells.
questions.hint: The decrease in urine pH and serum glucose indicates that the drug inhibits both ammonium and glucose production in the kidneys.

questions.text: A previously healthy 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for numbness and tingling in her legs for the past 2 months. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and dry scaly lips with cracks at the corner of the mouth. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased in both lower limbs. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.0 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Bone marrow biopsy shows erythroblasts with a ring of basophilic granules around the nucleus. This patient's condition is caused by the deficiency of a substrate that acts as a cofactor in which of following steps of catecholamine synthesis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine in the presence of the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB). Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

The amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine share a common catabolic pathway. At first, phenylalanine is converted to tyrosine catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase. This enzyme requires the cofactors tetrahydrobiopterin and dioxide. Tyrosine is then converted to 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate by tyrosine aminotransferase. The aromatic ring of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate is cleaved and the product is converted to fumarylacetoacetate by isomerization. Fumarate and acetoacetate are then produced by hydrolytic cleavage. Subsequently, acetoacetate can then be used to form acetoacetyl-CoA.

B) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of tyrosine to L-DOPA in the presence of the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB). Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

C) CORRECT:

DOPA decarboxylase catalyzes the conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine in the presence of the cofactor pyridoxal phosphate (active form of vitamin B6), which also serves as a cofactor in multiple other reactions, such as cystathionine synthesis, heme synthesis, decarboxylation, and transamination reactions. Clinical features of vitamin B6 deficiency include glossitis, gingivostomatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia, as observed in the patient.
Image Description:

Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).

The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.

Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

D) INCORRECT:

Dopamine β-hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine in the presence of the cofactors vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and Cu2+. Clinical features of vit. C deficiency include follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular hemorrhage, ecchymoses, gingivitis, and impaired wound healing, which are not observed here. Moreover, most patients with vit. C deficiency will have either normocytic anemia (due to decreased iron absorption in small intestine) or macrocytic anemia (due to decreased conversion of folate to its active metabolite, folinic acid), unlike this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase catalyzes the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine in the presence of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), which donates a methyl group to norepinephrine. Synthesis and regeneration of SAM require the presence of vitamin B12 and folic acid. Patients with vit. B12 deficiency or folic acid deficiency have low SAM levels, which leads to the development of megaloblastic anemia, unlike this patient's findings.
Image Description:

The coenzyme S-Adenosyl methionine (SAM) is composed of three parts: methionine (red), ribose (blue), and adenine (black). It plays an important role as a cofactor in methylation reactions.
questions.hint: In a patient taking an oral contraceptive, clinical features of peripheral neuropathy (paresthesias, decreased sensation in the extremities) and sideroblastic anemia (microcytic hypochromic anemia with sideroblasts in the bone marrow) suggest a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with depression comes to the physician because of easy bruising and bleeding of her gums for the past 2 months. She has been living alone since the death of her husband 1 year ago. She appears thin and has temporal wasting bilaterally. Physical examination shows bruises on her lower legs, swollen gums, and petechiae on the hard palate. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to defective synthesis of a substance that is composed primarily of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Collagen is a protein with the repeating amino acid sequence (Gly-X-Y). Since glycine is always on the first position of this triplet, it makes up for ⅓ of amino acids in a collagen molecule. On position X there is most commonly proline (second most common: lysine or hydroxylysine) and on position Y most commonly hydroxyproline (second most common: lysine or hydroxylysine). Vitamin C is needed as a cofactor in collagen synthesis for the hydroxylation of proline residue to hydroxyproline and of lysine residue to hydroxylysine.

B) INCORRECT:

Proline is a nonessential amino acid with hydrophobic properties. Although it is part of collagen, only 13.5% of total amino acids in collagen are proline.

C) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine is a nonessential amino acid with hydrophilic properties. It is part of signal-transduction pathways (tyrosine kinase) and plays an important role in the synthesis of catecholamines. It is not part of collagen.

The last step in the norepinephrine synthesis from tyrosine requires vitamin C as a cofactor (dopamine → norepinephrine).

D) INCORRECT:

Lysine is a basic, essential amino acid with hydrophilic properties. Although it is part of collagen, only 3 or 4% of total amino acids in collagen are lysine.

E) INCORRECT:

Arginine is a basic, conditionally essential amino acid. It plays an important role in the urea cycle and is part of histone proteins. It is not found in collagen.

F) INCORRECT:

Alanine is a nonessential, nonpolar amino acid; it is not part of collagen.

Alanine plays an important role in the glucose-alanine cycle (Cahill cycle), which allows the body to produce glucose from alanine created during muscle protein degradation.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (swollen gums, bruises, mucosal bleeding) in the setting of undernutrition (thin appearance, temporal wasting) are suggestive of vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen.

questions.text: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician because of somnolence, poor feeding, and vomiting after his first few breast feedings. He appears lethargic. His respiratory rate is 73/min. Serum ammonia is markedly increased. Genetic analysis shows deficiency in N-acetylglutamate synthase. The activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely directly affected by this genetic defect?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

N-acetylglutamate increases the activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1), a mitochondrial enzyme that converts bicarbonate and ammonia to carbamoyl phosphate using 2 molecules of ATP. This process is the rate-limiting step of the urea cycle. N-acetylglutamate is synthesized primarily in the liver and small intestinal cells when the cellular concentration of arginine is increased. In this way, the activity of CPS1 is increased following a protein-rich meal, when ammonia production is expected to be increased.

The two most common hereditary defects in the urea cycle are ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency) and CPS1 deficiency. Neonates with either of these defects are usually normal at birth but present with vomiting, lethargy, hyperventilation, and cerebral edema (due to intracellular accumulation of glutamine) after the first 24–72 hours as a result of introduction of dietary protein. In addition to increased ammonia levels in blood, they have increased glutamine and decreased blood urea nitrogen. OTC deficiency can be differentiated from CPS1 deficiency by the presence of orotic acid in urine.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

B) INCORRECT:

Ornithine translocase is a mitochondrial protein that is critical for urea cycle activity because it transports ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria, where it is converted to citrulline by ornithine transcarbamylase. A defect in ornithine translocase would cause hyperammonemia, but this protein's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Ornithine transcarbamylase is a mitochondrial enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it transfers a carbamoyl group onto ornithine to form citrulline. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinate synthetase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it synthesizes argininosuccinate from aspartate and citrulline. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it converts arginosuccinate to arginine and fumarate. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Arginase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it converts arginine to urea and ornithine. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.
questions.hint: N-acetylglutamate synthase produces N-acetylglutamate, which serves as an allosteric activator for one of the two enzymatic reactions of the urea cycle that take place in the mitochondria.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the chemical characteristics of a proteinogenic essential L-amino acid. The compound can metabolize into glucose, is a weak base, and has a neutral charge at physiological pH. The derivative of this amino acid is most likely to cause which of the following effects in the human body?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acidic ketone bodies (e.g., acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate) are derived from ketogenic amino acids such as leucine, lysine, isoleucine, phenylalanine, threonine, and tyrosine. Histidine, which is a purely glucogenic amino acid, does not give rise to ketone bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Melanin is responsible for skin pigmentation. Melanin is derived from phenylalanine or tyrosine via the intermediary DOPA rather than from histidine.

C) INCORRECT:

Catecholamines, such as epinephrine and norepinephrine, cause pupillary dilation, along with several other adrenergic effects. Both molecules are derived from phenylalanine or tyrosine, not histidine.

D) CORRECT:

Histamine is a vasoactive amine and inflammatory mediator, whose effects include vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, and edema. It is also a vital component of anaphylactic reactions. Histamine is derived from histidine via decarboxylation by the enzyme histidine decarboxylase, which requires the presence of vitamin B6 as a cofactor.

Nitric oxide, which is another vasodilatory substance, is derived from the amino acid arginine.

E) INCORRECT:

Tissue oxygenation is largely dependent on hemoglobin. Heme is derived from porphyrins, which are, in turn, synthesized from the amino acid glycine. Heme is not derived from histidine.

F) INCORRECT:

Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) induces respiratory depression by inhibiting neuronal excitation in the respiratory center of the brain. GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter synthesized from the amino acid glutamate.
questions.hint: Histidine is a weak base that metabolizes into glucose and has a neutral charge at physiological pH.

questions.text: A 4-day-old male newborn delivered at 39 weeks' gestation is evaluated because of poor feeding, recurrent vomiting, and lethargy. Physical examination shows tachypnea with subcostal retractions. An enzyme assay performed on a liver biopsy specimen shows decreased activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I. This enzyme plays an important role in the breakdown and excretion of amino groups that result from protein digestion. Which of the following is an immediate substrate for the synthesis of the molecule needed for the excretion of amino groups?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

N-acetylglutamate is an allosteric activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, which is the rate-limiting enzyme of urea synthesis. However, N-acetylglutamate is not a substrate for any of the enzymes involved in urea synthesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Valine is a substrate for the enzyme branched-chain amino acid aminotransferase, which produces alpha-keto acids (e.g., alpha-ketoisovalerate). Valine is not a substrate for enzymes involved in urea synthesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Homocysteine is a substrate for methionine synthase and cystathionine synthase. Homocysteine is not a substrate for enzymes involved in urea synthesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Homogentisate is a substrate for the enzyme homogentisate oxidase, which synthesizes maleylacetoacetate. Maleylacetoacetate is converted to fumarate, which is used for energy generation in the TCA cycle. Fumarate is a byproduct of the urea cycle, but homogentisate, maleylacetoacetate, and fumarate are not substrates for enzymes involved in urea synthesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine is a substrate for many enzymes, including phenylalanine hydroxylase, which produces tyrosine, and aromatic amino acid decarboxylase, which produces phenethylamine. Phenylalanine is also a substrate for certain transaminases, which produce phenylketones, such as phenylpyruvate, phenyllactate, and phenylacetate. Phenylalanine is not a substrate for enzymes involved in urea synthesis.

F) CORRECT:

Urea, which is the primary molecule for eliminating nitrogenous waste generated by protein digestion, is produced by the urea cycle, which is a series of enzymatic reactions that occur in the mitochondria and cytosol of hepatocytes. Argininosuccinate synthetase is one of the cytosolic enzymes involved in this process that forms argininosuccinate from citrulline and the amino acid aspartate. Argininosuccinate is then converted to the amino acid arginine by argininosuccinase, and arginine is again cleaved into urea and ornithine. Aspartate is also a substrate for the enzymes aspartate aminotransferase and dihydroorotate dehydrogenase.

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.
questions.hint: Amino groups are excreted in the form of urea.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of recurrent vomiting and poor feeding. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 2877 g (6 lb 6 oz); he currently weighs 2989 g (6 lb 9 oz). He appears lethargic. Physical examination shows weak muscle tone and hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show increased serum concentrations of ketones and branched-chain organic acids. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.21 and an HCO3- concentration of 11 mEq/L. Further evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is seen in von Gierke disease and Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Von Gierke disease can also manifest during the neonatal period with failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, mild ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. However, von Gierke disease is not associated with the presence of branched-chain organic acids in serum. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome can cause failure to thrive and lethargy, both of which are seen here, but this disorder is usually asymptomatic for the first 6 months of life and it does not manifest with metabolic acidosis, ketosis, or organic acidemia; instead, it presents in childhood with choreoathetosis, dystonia, cognitive impairment, and self-mutilating behavior.

B) INCORRECT:

Myoglobinuria (due to rhabdomyolysis) is seen in carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency (CPT II deficiency), which can manifest in the neonatal period with failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, metabolic acidosis, and increased serum levels of saturated and unsaturated dicarboxylic acids, both of which are organic acids. However, these dicarboxylic acids are unbranched unlike the increased serum concentrations of branched-chain organic acids that are seen in this neonate. In addition, CPT II deficiency does not result in ketosis; instead, it causes cardiomyopathy and/or arrhythmias.

C) CORRECT:

The organic acid accumulation that occurs in branched-chain organic acidemias causes hyperammonemia by inhibiting the urea cycle, a process that converts nitrogenous waste (e.g., ammonia) to urea for excretion. This organic acid build-up also inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes the oxidation of fatty acids to ketone bodies (an alternative energy source), thereby resulting in ketotic hypoglycemia. Increased serum concentrations of both ketones and branched-chain organic acids leads to high-anion gap metabolic acidosis. The most common type of branched-chain organic acidemia is methylmalonic acidemia (MMA), an autosomal recessive condition that is typically due to a defect in methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, an enzyme that converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Other examples of branched-chain organic acidemias include propionic acidemia and isovaleric acidemia.

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is also associated with the accumulation of branched-chain organic acids (branched-chain α-keto acids) and metabolic acidosis but, for reasons that are not completely understood, hypoglycemia and hyperammonemia are unusual in patients with MSUD. Defects in fatty acid beta-oxidation (e.g., medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency) would also cause organic acid accumulation, hyperammonemia, and hypoglycemia but not ketosis. Also, the organic acids that accumulate in fatty acid oxidation defects are typically linear, unbranched dicarboxylic acids. Primary defects of the urea cycle (e.g., ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency) would result in hyperammonemia but not ketosis.
Image Description:

The amino acids methionine, isoleucine, valine, and threonine are metabolized to succinyl-CoA via propionyl-CoA and methylmalonyl-CoA. Succinyl-CoA is introduced into the citric acid cycle and can, when required, enter into gluconeogenesis via oxaloacetate.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucosuria can be seen in Fanconi syndrome, which can manifest with vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, failure to thrive, hypotonia, and metabolic acidosis (due to proximal RTA), all of which are seen here. In addition, hepatomegaly could be indicative of an underlying cause of Fanconi syndrome such as von Gierke disease or tyrosinemia. However, Fanconi syndrome is not associated with an increase in serum levels of branched-chain organic acids.

E) INCORRECT:

Galactosemia is seen in galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (classic galactosemia), which can manifest during the neonatal period with vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, failure to thrive, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and metabolic acidosis (due to proximal RTA), all of which are seen here. However, it does not cause ketosis or organic acidemia. In addition, this neonate does not have other typical clinical features of classic galactosemia such as cataracts, diarrhea, and jaundice.

F) INCORRECT:

Orotic aciduria is caused by uridine monophosphate synthase (UMPS) deficiency, which can manifest during the neonatal period with failure to thrive, lethargy, and possibly metabolic acidosis due to high serum levels of orotic acid. However, orotic acid is not a branched-chain organic acid, and UMPS deficiency does not cause hypotonia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, or the presence of ketone bodies in serum; instead, orotic aciduria would cause megaloblastic anemia and urinary tract obstruction.
questions.hint: Metabolic acidosis (low pH with low HCO3-) and branched-chain organic acids in serum indicate a branched-chain organic acidemia, which typically manifests with vomiting, poor feeding, failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly within a few weeks to months of life.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man from a region with limited food availability presents with a 4-month history of muscle wasting, lower extremity edema, and a scaly rash. His diet consists almost entirely of homemade wheat bread, with very limited intake of legumes, dairy, or meat. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen, thinning hair, and bilateral leg swelling. Laboratory studies show a decreased serum albumin concentration. Which of the following amino acids is most severely depleted in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspartate is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from oxaloacetate, which can be synthesized endogenously from citric acid cycle intermediates such as pyruvate and malate.

B) INCORRECT:

Glutamine is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized endogenously from glutamate and ammonia. Glutamate can be produced from intermediates of the citric acid cycle (e.g., α-ketoglutarate) and transamination reactions involving other nonessential amino acids.

C) INCORRECT:

Although important in the glucose-alanine cycle, alanine is nonessential because it can be synthesized by transamination of citric acid cycle intermediates such as pyruvate.

D) INCORRECT:

Serine is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from glycolytic intermediates such as 3-phosphoglycerate.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has features of kwashiorkor (e.g., abdominal distention, muscle wasting, edema, hypoalbuminemia), which is caused by a protein-deficient diet. Essential amino acids cannot be synthesized in the body from other amino acids or the metabolites of carbohydrates and fats; they must be obtained via dietary protein. The essential amino acids are leucine, lysine, phenylalanine, isoleucine, threonine, tryptophan, methionine, and valine. Cereal grains like wheat are notably deficient in lysine, which makes them an incomplete protein source. Arginine and histidine are conditionally essential amino acids (i.e., may become essential during times of increased demand), and the endogenous production of some nonessential amino acids depends on having an adequate supply of essential amino acids. The strictly nonessential amino acids are alanine, asparagine, aspartate, glutamine, and serine, which can be synthesized even in the absence of essential amino acids.

Key learning point: The essential amino acids are leucine, lysine, phenylalanine, isoleucine, threonine, tryptophan, methionine, and valine.
questions.hint: This amino acid is purely ketogenic, is positively charged at body pH, and does not have a branched side chain.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of palpitations, shortness of breath, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps for 2 months. Physical examination shows cutaneous flushing of the face. Auscultation of the chest shows bilateral wheezing. A 24-hour urine collection shows increased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) concentration. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows an intestinal tumor with extensive metastasis to the liver. A diagnosis of an inoperable disease is made, and the patient is started on treatment with octreotide. Six weeks later, the patient's symptoms have improved except for his abdominal pain and frequent loose stools. The physician suggests enrolling the patient in a trial to test additional treatment with a new drug that has been shown to improve symptoms in other patients with the same condition. The expected beneficial effect of this new drug is most likely caused by inhibition of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dopamine beta-hydroxylase is an enzyme of catecholamine synthesis that converts dopamine into noradrenaline. Although elevated catecholamines can lead to palpitations, shortness of breath, and facial flushing, this patient's symptoms are caused by excess serotonin. This enzyme is not involved in serotonin synthesis, so inhibition of dopamine beta-hydroxylase is unlikely to improve this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) is a hormone that can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and flushing. However, carcinoid syndrome is not associated with elevated VIP levels, so VIP inhibition is unlikely to improve this patient's symptoms. Abnormally increased VIP is seen in patients with VIPomas, which can also be treated with octreotide.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasma kallikrein is part of the kinin cascade, which releases bradykinin from high-molecular-weight kininogen. Bradykinin excess can cause dyspnea, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Although excess production of kallikrein can cause carcinoid syndromes, kallikrein inhibitors (e.g., ecallantide) are not approved for treating these syndromes. These agents are used to treat bradykinin excess in hereditary angioedema.

D) INCORRECT:

Histidine decarboxylase converts histidine to histamine, which can cause anaphylactic symptoms such as dyspnea, wheezing, cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Carcinoid syndromes can be caused by excess production of this vasoactive substance, so reducing histamine levels may be beneficial, but there are no histidine decarboxylase inhibitors currently approved for clinical use.

E) CORRECT:

Tryptophan hydroxylase is an enzyme that converts tryptophan into serotonin. Carcinoid syndromes are caused by the excess production of various vasoactive substances; serotonin is the most prominent and is the primary cause of gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea). Telotristat, an inhibitor of tryptophan hydroxylase, is used as adjunctive therapy for patients with carcinoid syndromes whose diarrhea is not controlled with somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide).
Image Description:

Important cofactors and constituents appear in blue boxes.
questions.hint: Palpitations, dyspnea with wheezing, flushing, and diarrhea in a patient with a metastatic intestinal tumor and increased urinary 5-HIAA suggest carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of prolonged stiffness in the morning and progressive pain and swelling of her wrists and hands over the past 4 months. Examination shows bilateral swelling and mild tenderness of the wrists and the second, third, and fourth metacarpophalangeal joints. Her range of motion is limited by pain. Serum studies show elevated anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Treatment with methotrexate is begun. At a follow-up examination, her serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) concentration is 75 U/L and her serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) concentration is 81 U/L. Which of the following substances is essential for the function of these enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a precursor to NAD+ and NADP+, which function as cofactors in redox reactions. Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra and glossitis. However, neither niacin nor its derivatives are required for transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiamine pyrophosphate, the active form of thiamine (vitamin B1), serves as a cofactor for several enzymes of carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism. Thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and Beriberi. However, it is not involved in transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

C) INCORRECT:

Biotin (vitamin B7) is a cofactor for various carboxylation enzymes, including acetyl-CoA carboxylase, methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase, and propionyl-CoA carboxylase. Biotin deficiency can cause dermatitis, enteritis, and alopecia. However, it is not involved in transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

D) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is a cofactor in hydroxylation and redox reactions. Importantly, it serves as a coenzyme to lysyl and prolyl hydroxylase, which are essential to collagen synthesis. However, it is not required for transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

E) INCORRECT:

Tetrahydrofolate, the active form of folic acid (vitamin B9), is a cofactor for methylation reactions such as those essential to nucleic acid synthesis. Folic acid deficiency can result in megaloblastic anemia and, in the case of maternal deficiency, in neural tube defects. However, it is not required for the transamination reactions performed by AST and ALT.

F) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is a precursor to flavin mononucleotide and flavin adenine dinucleotide, which serve as cofactors for numerous enzymes (e.g., acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, glutathione reductase). Riboflavin deficiency can cause cheilosis and conjunctivitis with corneal vascularization. However, vitamin B2 derivatives do not participate in transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

G) CORRECT:

Pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of pyridoxine (vitamin B6), is an important cofactor in the transamination reactions performed by AST and ALT. Moreover, it is required for glycogen phosphorylase reactions, decarboxylation, and synthesis of cystathionine, heme, niacin, and histamine, as well as several neurotransmitters.

Methotrexate is the disease-modifying antirheumatic drug of choice for patients diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and may cause minor transaminitis or, in rare cases, severe drug-induced liver injury.
questions.hint: Aminotransferases catalyze transamination reactions, in which the amino group of one amino acid is transferred to an α-ketoacid, forming an amino acid. Deficiency of the cofactor required for transaminations is associated with irritability, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia.
